oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Quintin Miller Smith memorial service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A program from the memorial service for Quintin Miller Smith. Smith was president of the institution from 1938-1958.

Interestingly, the program for the memorial service of Smith was acquired quite by accident. Walker, Digital Initiatives purchased extra copies of The First Fifty Years by Homer Pittard, and the program was tucked within the pages of one of the volumes.

Memorial Services In Remembrance 01 QUINTIN MILLER SMITH President Middle Tennessee State University Murfreesboro, Tennessee from September 1, 1938 until September 1, 1958 In Memorium Tennessee Room Student Union Building Middle Tennessee State University April 8, 1976 2: 00 p. m. Personification of consistent achievement in a career dedicated to the improvement of education, Q. M. Smith served as a college president for 38 years, longer than any other person in Tennessee history. A man who loved young people, understood them, shared in their joys and sorrows their ambitions and achievements he was one who was regarded with esteem and appreci~ tion. In 1911, as Middle Tennessee Normal first opened, a young man with four years teaching experience in his native Humphreys County, enrolled with aspirations to improve as a teacher. Asserting leadership in forensics, publications, and scholarship Mr. Smith graduated from the Normal to move on to the University of Tennessee and later to Peabody College where he earned the B. S. and M. A. degrees. While successfully filling a high school principalship he studied law at night and became a licensed member of the bar Organ Prelude Scripture- Praye " Open Our Eyes" - McFarlane University Varsity Choir Presiding ... ~, ributes: . Mrs. Margaret Wright Dr. Robert Garrigus Directed by" Mr. Neil Wright Dr. M. G. Scarlett He became President of Tennessee Polytechnic Institute in 1920. Then, in 1938 when Middle Tennessee State College sought a third president to bring the institution out of the diminution and confusion of ~ he exhausting years of the Great Depression, Q. M. Smith was chosen. As a product of this school he became the source of reinvigoration that saw a student body increase from 550 to 2,245, the erection of 13 new permanent structures, the growth of the campus from 205 to 604 acres with a comparable increase in staff. With rare perspkacity he developed a comprehensive conspectus for the expansion of professional, vocational, and liberal arts programs that were ultimately to culminate in University status. Scarlett Mr. Eugene Sloan Although education, his own a~ d that of others, was the driving force in Mr. Smith's life, he was a dedicated family man and active in the work of his church, civic and fraternal orders. He was twice President of the Tennessee Education Association, President . of the Tennessee College Association, chairman of the committee that framed the Tennessee Teacher Retirement System, a member of the Board of Directors of the Chamber · of Commerce, a bank vice- president, : Chairman of the Rutherford County Democratic Executive Committee and the Planning Committee. He was a commissioner and vice- president of the Tennessee Council of the Boy Scouts of America and was awarded the two top adult honors of that organization. He was an intensively patriotic citizen. He served as a commissioned officer in the Navy in World War I and retired as a major USAR. This interest led him to bring the ROTC program to MTSU and to maintain membership in the American Legion for more than half a century. The University is indeed proud and thankful that Mr. Smith came this way. " Benediction and Seven- Fold Amen" - Lutkin University Varsity Choir ..... Directed by Mr. Neil Wright . f . f
